comments.commentBody:
Republicans could have won in 2008, even after Bush, if they ran something better than McCain and the Tina Fey look-alike.

If McCain died in office, Sarah Palin would have been POTUS.

This country was not really ready for a black president, hence the whole birther thing; but Sarah Palin, or a guy who would choose her?

And Obama is doing a very good job considering the economic environment and republican obstruction.

Ross, what you write is partially true, but you'd be well advised to read these reader comments carefully, because they will tell you the things you missed.  Your head is partially out of the sand, but if you make a list of the things these readers write about, you have a chance of pulling it the rest of the way out.  The Republican Party has a lot of work to do.  You don't need to just re-vamp your positions, you have to work hard in developing better candidates.  You need a leadership academy.  The Mittster may have been the best you had, but he was the best of a sorry lot.  Nobody's going to vote for Boehner, Jindal, McConnell, Perry, or Bachmann.  They are national disgraces.  You don't have a Hillary Clinton waiting in the wings for 2016.  Maybe Jeb Bush, but then again, there's that darn last name.
Douthat isn't about to point out the things Obama accomplished, after all he's just one more mouthpiece for Romney/Ryan/Cheney/etc, etc, etc.  Lather, rinse, repeat.

Mr. Douthat, I have always said that the most important reason Barack Obama became president was because of President Bush's incompetence on so many levels. In your blog you suggest that Romney is still moving into those head winds, and no doubt that's true. But you give Mr. Obama no credit whatsoever for his competence. The list of his accomplishments are long and impressive: He killed Bin Laden, he bailed out Detroit and saved not just the auto industry but numerous ancillary industries that work with that industry. He pushed through healthcare reform, something that Democratic presidents have failed at for generations. People might not like it now without a lot of information about it, but they will once they can't be tossed off their insurance for pre-existing conditions, for example. Even Mitt Romney likes that part of Obamacare. Obama quietly stopped genocide in Libya, which rebounded to overthrowing Gaddafi. He ended Don't ask don't tell. He signed the Lilly Ledbetter fair pay act as his first piece of legislation. He helped stem our slide into a depression. For crying out loud, what more can a president do in four years? When Republicans say he failed it boggles the mind. Could he have done more with jobs? Yes, but he was thwarted by Republicans on that score. They've watched how effective he's been in so many areas. They didn't want him effective in that one too.

Because they want to "take back their country" from a black man. That's all I can figure. Either that or they are so radically anti-gay and anti-abortion that nothing else matters to them.

Oh, wait. There's another reason. They make all their money from capital gains and are so greedy they want to pay ZERO income tax.

Those are the only reasons I could see, if they really looked at the issues and the candidates' positions.
What puzzles me is why anyone would vote Republican this year. Their blinkered vision of the Obama "failure" is a good example of the GOP's warped mindset.
And yet George W. Bush was elected to 2 terms.  This is what scares me about the future of our country.

Kate,

Annointed the first time by family retainers.

Gee, how could Romney possibly remind voters of George Bush?

Because they were both born to wealthy political fathers?
Because they both chose to be prep school cheerleaders?
Because they both avoided VietNam?
Because neither has ever done an honest days labor?
Because both see the technicolor world in black and white?
Because neither could talk his way out of a wet paper bag?

In other news, Politico is reporting that Lyin' Ryan bought $2 million in advertising to hold onto his seat in Congress.

The perfect summation of the current republican ethos, viz, every rat for himself.
cf Chris Christie.

I think it can all be summed up by the Peter Principle.
The ....... organization called the Republican Party has on the whole risen to the level of its own incompetence.

The final proof of this will forever more rest in the total failure as demonstrated and represented by the GW Bush Administration.
Romney/Ryan is simply the double down on everything that Bush and all the attending operatives brought bear on the nation and its citizenry - in every regard.

The Republican Party has outlived its usefulness - in every regard. RIP GOP.

Nothing worse can be said about the Republican party than that they totally ignored Huntsman, but seriously considered Gingrich, Perry, Bachman, Cain, and Stantorum; and finally defaulted to the empty suit Romney, who had an empty chair as the high-point of his convention.

And they are surprised that people don't want to vote for them?
Right.  Romney is a mediocrity. But compared to what he was running against, he was the obvious choice.

I think you have it half right.

Yet, the Bush debacle was highly touted by those who now recommend Romney-Ryan. Additionally, no one can say for sure what policy positions R-R has on anything, given that whatever few specifics they offer one day are contradicted the next. Romney rails against "Obamacare," then he says he would keep parts of it, and then he says he's against all of it. And all within the past few days.

Also, many people see the GOP efforts being made to suppress the vote in major swing states, and many think, correctly in my opinion, that this is not about the sanctity of the electoral process as it is a tactic to suppress participation of poor and ethnic minority voters. There is a great danger to democratic self-government lingering just below the surface here, and it is not just liberals who smell a rat. This should be both of conservative and liberal concern alike.

And yet, who else would be the standard bearer now, given the sub-sub-par class of candidates fielded by the GOP: Bachmann, Gingrich, Santorum, Perry, etc.? What is wrong with the GOP that it ia producing such weak candidates? Perhaps it needs seriously to look into its own soul to see if the Faustian deal they made with the financial underwriters of the Tea Party is now blowing up in their faces.

Paul,

Somehow you missed that in 4 long years and none of those responsable for what you list and more have gone to jail. That would be on President Obama's watch so that could be why.

That comes under the heading of Partisan doesn't it?
But don't forget, some Republicans in Ohio (and presumably elsewhere) think that Romney was responsible for the killing of Bin Laden.  And I still believe in the tooth fairy.

Good post, but you left out the fact that 9/11 occurred on Bush's watch.  According to a sobering article in the NYT yesterday based on hitherto secret documents, Bush had many warnings prior to September 2001 about an impending terrorist attack on America.  However, he and his neo-con advisors were too busy planning the invasion of Iraq to listen.  An alert president who was not obsessed with Saddam Hussein might have prevented the attack.

The love that dare not speak its name: The Republican's eight year affair with George W Bush. Mission Accomplished, dude!

It's why Romney didn't pick Condi to be his vice presidential nominee, despite all of the imprecations in these pages from Richard Luettgen. Even now, *especially* on this day, the title "Bin Laden Determined to Strike in US" hangs heavy over the Bush years. That and the Banking Collapse, the demises of Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers, and the unfurling of the TARP.

Good times, eh, Ross?

The funds may not be unlimited.

If large spending and the debates do not start moving the polls in the swing states in the next 4-5 weeks then the super-pacs with the unlimited funds may decide to use those funds to take the Senate, spending more in non-swing states like Mass and Missouri where the Senate will be decided, but with little effect on the electoral college.

It would be a disaster for the Kochs and Adelson to spend a few hundred million on elections and not buy anything.
Maybe, but hell will freeze over before I'll vote for Romney for anything.  I'm from Massachusetts, and we've long since had more than enough of him or his ilk.

Good piece, but missing a couple of points. The conservative commentators Mr. Douthat refers to are too convinced of the perfection of their own message. They fail to realize that there are a lot of elements to the hard-right agenda espoused in the convention platform which quite honestly turn off a lot of moderates who might otherwise be more reticent about giving Mr. Obama another four years. And the resistance of both Mr. Romney and Mr. Ryan to fill in the blanks about things like taxes and entitlement reform-which are key issues for the average American, erodes trust that Romney will be a good steward, as opposed to simply being a deliverer of spoils. Part of this mindset stems from is a peculiar arrogance, fed by the echo chamber of these same pundits, the talk show shock jocks, and Fox, that every rational person must realize that Mr. Obama is completely unworthy and that conservative principles are as self evident as those on the two tablets Moses brought from Mount Sinai.
But they aren't. Mr, Douthat isn't wrong to blame Bush, but he doesn't allow himself the extra self-knowledge that there may be unappetizing portions of the present Republican orthodoxy.
I still think Mr. Romney, aided by unlimited funds and a willingness to use all means at his disposal, has an excellent chance of winning.

syncopatedpolitics@blogspot.com

There you have it.  The Republican Party has laid itself on the biggest bomb we didn't need.  TWICE NOW.  Then the remaining insight is that when the politicians are rancid, so are the businessmen even MORE rancid.  Our institutions of insurance and banking are now trying to find ways to churn America's last dime into offshore accounts belonging to offshore owners.  NOT AMERICANS.  And Congress is sitting back and letting our country and its assets be taken by their stonewalling of our need for control of the operations of our economy.  If Congress doesn't wake up and operate in our Country's best interest, WE WON'T HAVE A COUNTRY.  But Congress is so busy until this year with stealing from other stock traders by insider trading that they are still ignoring that they have sewn the seeds of unethical behavior that should have seen them kicked out of their jobs... our Congress and senate leaders come in average well to do and go out millionaires... and not from earnings... but from similar thefts of knowledge not given to the public and not allowed to those they would steal equity from.  1890s chieftans were even more unethical, but these are worse by pretending to be caring citizen legislators.  TIME TO CLEAN HOUSE.  Take OUT the incumbents in legislation.  Shove away all representatives of the unethical Republican Party and bring on the libertarians, the isolationists, the nation builders, the true  Americans.

Romney made his millions through Bain Capital tearing up companies and loading them with debt... just like the Bush
adminstration and the Republicans did with the United States treasury. They made their money off of war and
companies going overseas and loaded the taxpayers with joblessness and debt.

Bush Legacy. Bain's Business model. "On September 15, 2007 all of the major credit-rating agencies downgraded AIG – the world's largest insurance company. At issue were the soaring losses in its credit default swaps. The first big writeoff came in the fourth quarter of 2007, when AIG reported an $11 billion charge. It was able to raise capital once, to repair the damage. But the losses kept growing. The moment the downgrade came, AIG was forced to come up with tens of billions of additional collateral, immediately. This was on top of the billions it owed to its trading partners. It didn't have the money. The world's largest insurance company was bankrupt.

The dominoes fell over immediately. Lehman Brothers failed on the same day. Merrill was sold to Bank of America. The Fed stepped in and agreed to lend AIG $85 billion to facilitate an orderly sell off of its assets in exchange for essentially all the company's equity."

As a lifelong Democrat, I really, really miss the old Republican Party of Dwight Eisenhower, William Buckley, and many others.  The current conglomeration of vultures, liars, and their dupes has no right to call itself by the same name as the party of Lincoln.  It is a national disgrace and a national catastrope.  We need "our father's" Republican party.

at patsy47, as a life long democrat I miss the old democrats. However, I'll take the ones we have over the repugs all the time.

Has anyone ever seen a Ronald Reagan film? They're awful. Some of them can be found for free on the Internet Archive. Google that and "feature film" or "TV" plus Reagan. Their search engine isn't very good but Google has it.

When you get to see Reagan in action it boggles the mind how he became President. History points out that he collaborated with the FBI while he was in Hollywood to get rid of his competition, then later when he became a public figure, and then he used this relationship to go after students in Berkley when it was known to the FBI that they were just students and not "commies" and their demands were just.

The American electorate is easily manipulated.

Ross, the intellectuals of your party are Ted Nugent and Sarah Palin (formerly of Wasilla). Take a look at the strong field that Romney had to run against. They were literate for the most part. I am sure that George Will holds them all in high esteem. What will happen to your party when it loses to Obama, fails to take the Senate and possibly loses the House? It will turn further to the right because you weren't conservative enough. Rick Santorum would have been so much better they will say. Truth really doesn't matter to your party, but it does to the American people. Good luck with that truthy-fact-checky- thing not really mattering.

There. Likes is a euphemistic term in the way you are using it. NO ONE TRUSTS HIM. Nothing is ever his fault. He continually injects himself into things that are not his watch and blusters outrageously on foreign situations. Does he want to blow up our world as his final insertion of his massive ego to make our world as rotten as his own ... which is truly a case of legalized theft from American corporate rules perspective and ignored cruelty from the view of Americans. The man is still a bully and needs to go home... or just go away.
We are tired of this man, tired of his party, tired of being thumped as a people for what his party has done in this double decade to make Americans feel ill at ease with all of them. Especially Congress.
I wish you were right about Missouri, but believe it or not, Akin could still win.
Oh come on. Ann likes him.

Pretty difficult for the GOP to win as a party when you've got senatorial candidates blowing states like *Missouri* and a Presidential candidate whose only real problem is that absolutely no one likes him.

You state "..... the good Republican candidates".
And who, pray tell, might they be. There are no "good Republican candidates".
Drop a few names on us so we can assess their credentials - assuming, of course, that any of their names are at all recognizable.
The Republican Party has outlived its usefulness because it has no "good Republican candidates". RIP.

And the same can be said of its ideology which has not stood the test of time.

Agreed -- Mr. Douthat would do well to connect ALL the dots, including the disastrous Republican circus of their primaries.

But, considering the performances of people such as Jeb Bush at the convention, it begs the question, 'ARE there any 'good' republican candidates at all -- especially any that would be acceptable to their own party?

What good Republican candidates? Only Ron Paul received enough delegates to be an alternate. And the do right ?wrong! party backed away. Not aberrant enough.

I have begun to think they KNOW finally what a lousy President GWBUSH was and they don't want the job of setting the nation right. They just want to tear down the opposition and continue snarking as they have the past four years and seeing that set of methodical nation slayers say no to every initiative makes me want to spank a bunch of UNPATRIOTIC LOUSY Legislators Lacking Character.

Interesting column, especially the view that the Republicans should win this race. One must admit that the most of the final contenders for the nomination - Santorum, Bachman, Gingrich, Perry, and Cain were close to laughable or grotesque. Serious, circumspective, non-moralizing candidates were few: Romney, Huntsman, Pawlenty and the latter two dropped out early.

There is a simple way to analyze the situation - the good Republican candidates are waiting for 2016. They know that it is tough to beat an incumbent.

True, WR, but true for BOTH parties.
The fact is that the American people want democrat benefits and entitlements, and republican taxes.
They also want diet prime rib for dinner.

You can't square that circle. As was said once about possible nuclear war, "the winner may envy the loser."

Oh yes, Ross, it's the lying.  I'm sure a lot of Americans are ignorant and don't bother to check the things they're told by Lyin' Ryan and Faux News.  But a lot of us are not ignorant, we don't watch Fox, and we do check what we're told.  The magnitude of Republicans' lies in the last four years (and, of course, the eight before that) far exceeds Lyin' Ryan's marathon time.  That one was merely symptomatic.  Romney's stories about Bain, his time in Utah, and his time as governor--well, they simply turn people off.

Oh yes, Ross, it's the lying. I'm sure a lot of Americans are ignorant and don't bother to check the things they're told by Lyin' Ryan and Faux News. But a lot of us are not ignorant, we don't watch Fox, and we do check what we're told. The magnitude of Republicans' lies in the last four years (and, of course, the eight before that) far exceeds Lyin' Ryan's marathon time. That one was merely symptomatic. Romney's stories about Bain, his time in Utah, and his time as governor--well, they simply turn people off.

Using Fox News are your propaganda arm was a risky bet, and it looks like it's costing you now. When 60% of Republicans aren't sure if Obama's an American, aren't sure about Darwin, and aren't sure who killed bin Laden, you've got a problem. Some of us don't want the USA to become Mississippi.

For a change, Mr. Douthat has written a sensible column.   But Dave also points out what Mr. Douthat has omitted: that the entire Romney-Ryan campaign is based on lies.  What Dave left out is that there is a reason the entire Romney-Ryan campaign is based on lies: because if they campaigned on anything like the truth they would have absolutely no chance of winning.

Joel Pond: There was not a problem with Medicare and Medicaid before the tax cuts in 2002. It takes some balls to cut revenues severely and double the defense budget and then blame the resulting fiscal mess on payments that go to the sick and the elderly. There is nothing brave about it.

Restore the tax rates to the Clinton era rates and cut defense spending by half and we will be just fine.

...or Ryan's "miraculous" budget plan that restores our fiscal future - by lumping nearly $900 billion in cuts into an unspecified "miscellaneous" category.  If this is the "genius" of the conservative movement, I'd hate to see who the slow thinkers are.

And what is sad, if he, Romney, gets the White House and IS able to throw out "Obamacare" on the first day of office as he promises - then there literally WILL be people dying, before they know how R/R will provide those without healthcare, healthcare.

But what are a few more medical related deaths, when there is so much prestige to be gained!

I do NOT believe for a minute the Romney feels lives are more important than increases in defense spending.

WHAT relatively brave proposals on entitlement reform?  Are you the guy with the 18 minutes of missing tape? Please please tell us which tax loopholes Ryan will close - he's too brave to get into specifics.  And how is it that Romney will courageously keep every aspect of the ACA other than the mandate, and still balance the budget?  We are all dying to know.

The German player, by the way, is now TFC's captain, Torsten Frings who handled on the line. FIFA decided Dallas was good enough to be fourth official in the WC Final that year. Sure, FIFA is utterly corrupt, but how does not qualifying, let alone not qualifying now, punish anybody BUT our team (and ESPN)?

I just got back from a trip to Salvador, Brazil and Buenos Aires, and Salvador was definitely a bit more expensive than BA in terms of (nice) restaurants and just generally due to the exchange rates.  However, lodging in Salvador was very reasonable, the street food (acaraje!) is fantastic, beer is cheap, and one of the main attractions -- the Lacerdo elevator -- costs the equivalent of about eight cents to ride.  Salvador is definitely an affordable alternative to the larger, more happening cities of the south, and the beaches there were gorgeous.
First of all, it's TIananmen Square. Second, England, France, et al did carve China up into spheres of influence. Do you know your history? You need to get educated.

Sanjey,

You're right. It doesn't matter. But I'm not sure about your point to this discussion. It seems to be irrelevant.

It seems that the Chinese government is deadly serious of settling its long term dispute with Japan by deploying its military this time. Pressured by its internal conflicts within the communist party and domestic social stress, it is seeking a national unity over an external threat. This will have series unperdictable consequences, if Japan is not going to back down. Russia and Korea are waiting at the other end of the table to get their share or revenge. US no longer has the same power in south Asia to restrain Chinese government. Now, a smart move from US government would be to pressure Japan to return back the islands.

http://www.forbes.com/sites/stephenharner/2012/09/11/japans-future-depen...

As Chinese, I could not articulate this island dispute any better than Mr. Stephen Harner, a long-term Japan/Asia expert.

"the crisis’s sharp escalation has forced thoughtful Japanese to consider the costs to their country of severe, long term political and economic estrangement from China. What the analysis reveals is that prolonged political and, especially, economic and social estrangement from China would be an unmitigated disaster for the Japanese nation.

The truth is, not only today and tomorrow, but even more so in the years and decades ahead, as Japan’s economy matures and its population shrinks and ages, continued growth and prosperity of Japan’s economy and society will require increasingly deep and broad integration with a more vibrant Asia, and particularly with China."

"In just the economic sphere, it is clear that China is going to retaliate, probably massively, against Japanese business interests. It must be profoundly feared that the economic damage will be severe and prolonged."

the communist party gone soft lately as the old red gaurd has been replaced by the bougeouse educated mandarins.  before communist party was controlled the red army from the 1949 communist war and courts wore military green uniforms

when you say something, please think about your ownselves, what about the invasion of the pearl harbor by japan in the second world war ? what about the terrist of 911? what the attitude toward to you America from the citizen or P.R.goverment ? Maybe your Americans forgot the spirit of your independent war and civil war, forget the spirit from 1775--1783, forgot the gun of Lexington,forgot the great Lincoln who died for your democracy, forgot the Marting Luther King for the equality between the W and the B, forgot the "fat" and the "little boy" .
But please remember that in your heart Tibet is a tightly part of China, we are the same skin, same color of eyes, same culture and same language, the black hair you can see even from the high sky! The yellow river and Changjiang river are our mother river and which feed our nation. The 5,000 years history made us to be one family, it just like your family members, you might be not agree with each other for some reason, but you can not deny that you are relatives, you are a whole family. what about your neighbour robbed your kids to their family? You think it is usual, or you fight for your kids?

To Larrmoe 2012:
Wasn't it the same slave owners who founded the U.S. and came up with the same constitution that celebrated the inviolable rights to life, liberty, and happiness while explicitly depriving the Afro-Americans their civil rights and equality in political participation, the same constitution that was not changed in this regard until the 14th amendment, and is still the supreme law of the land of freedom?

All I found in these comments made me feel a little astonished for some mistaken opinion about China. China is always the most peaceful country in the world from long ago to now. The chinese people do want to live a peaceful and happiness life. the goverment of our country is kindly and friendly to each country even the country which had invaded our motherland and killed millions of our citizen. But DO NOT consider our friendly talk and morderate activities to be weak or coward !!  If the japanese illigely  invade our territory, they will be punished just like their broken ambition in the second world war!

Frank- you came real close. We have lots of adverseries to worry about but it is more politically correct to indicate the currently reviled enemy. Frankly (a pun) , I laugh at the idea of Iran being a nuclear aggresor but they are a convenient enemy to make an example of to all the rest of the world without ticking off the entire world. Do you catch my drift? It's militant diplomacy. We need some saints in the State Department.

Still don't get it Robert, keep thinking. Reread the article.
If you challenge me again, make it enlightening.

Incestuous, revolving door, experts.
Whose main expertise is sniffing out DoD dollars.

Try looking at that theory and results at the University of Maine.  This experiment began long ago up here with very unfortunate results, including a fractured system gobbling up its own students and potential students and vying for programs.

I'm sorry, but I teach online and so does my husband. If that is the future, it will surely be a sad an ignorant one. Won't it be great when we have a few academic megastars recording videos and army's of teaching assistants making $10 an hour. I'm sure young people will have the patience, diligence and time management skills to watch videos, read kindle books and take multiple choice tests. The teaching assistants should be great for that kind of pay. They would probably only require an AA degree from an online college. No benefits of course.

But don't worry, there will still be regular colleges for those with means.

Online education is not a panacea and there is no disease anyhow. It is great for adults who are committed and must work and raise families and for some general education, but it is not a quality education. I teach at a Community College online in a very poor and remote region of the country. My class is not hard, but it does require effort. Out of 24 students beginning the course 5 or 6 will pass. Most just stop completing any work at all and ignore all emails and referrals. This is not the answer to everything.

Try READING the article. For your enlightenment:

"Chartered by Congress to give scientific and technical advice to the government, the council is considered to be the nation’s preeminent group of scientists. The 16-person panel consists of scientists, engineers and weapons experts from universities, research groups and national laboratories, including one in Livermore, Calif., that deals with nuclear arms."
